nsparis wrote:

>You are referring to what I am doing as an "integration" test.  Do 
>you think this is no longer a unit test when I start making sure that 
>the messenger is respondeing correctly when something is added?  
>  
>

The meaning of "unit" in "unit test" is ambiguous, at best.  Many of my 
unit tests actually test a constellation of objects, not a specific 
object in isolation. So in that respect, debating whether it's a unit 
test or an integration test is splitting hairs.

>Should the unit test only make sure that the addMessage() method is 
>working (I.e. it received the message), and the integration test 
>should then make sure that when a certain message is added it 
>recieves the correct response message via the listener?
>  
>

My personal style would be to test the guts of addMessage() without 
having to sleep anywhere in the test.  Sleeping takes time and will 
ultimately cause my test suite to run slower than I'd like.  So I'd try 
to test the behavior synchronously. If that were difficult, I'd take a 
lesson from the pain and try to rework the design such that it was 
possible. Then I might write a unit/integration test one layer removed 
to get confident about the asynchronous aspects, if I feared it might break.

Do whatever gives you confidence and simply call it a test.

Mike
